Can you cheat a psychometric test? http://on.ft.com/1h6MN3g 

The best tests will assume that people lie and will take that into account. The only way really to fake a test is to be able to understand how the scoring works. 

Take the statement: "I have a great sense of humour". People who are genuinely funny, as rated by others, rather than themselves, tend to answer no, while people who are not funny tend to answer yes.

4 things you might not know about tuberculosis: http://on.ft.com/1ropPHP

For all its Marxist rhetoric, China's political system is really quite medieval, with palace coups, bitter factional fights and hereditary rule by a small and insular aristocracy who describe themselves as "red-bloods" (rather than blue bloods) in a nod to their revolutionary roots. Putin to pardon Mikhail Khodorkovsky: http://on.ft.com/1gIbAKt

Vladimir Putin will pardon Mikhail Khodorkovsky, finally allowing one of Russia's most famous prisoners to walk free after more than a decade behind bars. Mr Putin said he had come to his decision after receiving a letter from Mr Khodorkovsky, a former oil tycoon, asking for clemency. 

The announcement comes a day after the Russian government granted amnesty to more than a dozen other prisoners whose cases had been criticised in the west as politically motivated. Jailed members of the female punk band Pussy Riot will also be freed, as will Greenpeace protesters who protested on a drilling platform in Russia's Arctic.

Image by Getty.

Free to read: Dilbert's creator on life beyond the cubicle: http://on.ft.com/1i3AmEY

There are three frames to the typical Dilbert comic strip. Scott Adams, the creator of the mordant office satire, talks as though his own career has only just reached the third frame and, once completed, will have a punchline better than any he has written so far. The twist: the simply drawn everyman-engineer Dilbert will not be in it.

Is Egypt sliding back into authoritarianism? http://on.ft.com/1jirP2N

Yet again in the throes of an often violent transition, Egypt seems to have turned full circle since the January 2011 uprising that ended the autocratic rule of Hosni Mubarak and ignited hopes of a democratic future. Once again, the security agencies are resurgent, thousands of Islamists are in prison and the democracy activists who launched the revolution are harassed and branded foreign agents and saboteurs. To many, Mr Mubarak may be out of the picture, but "Mubarakism" is staging a comeback.

Farewell to five years of cheap cash? http://on.ft.com/1hl5YTZ

For the second time in three months, world markets are braced for the beginning of the end of history's greatest monetary experiment. The Federal Reserve's open market committee meets on Wednesday to decide whether to start to taper the $85bn it is spending each month on buying US bonds. Whenever the taper happens, the process of ending easy money has begun - and no one quite knows what will happen next.

Free to read: How will a Fed taper affect fragile emerging markets economies? http://on.ft.com/1kUEoNc

The economies of Brazil, India, Indonesia, South Africa and Turkey have been identified as particularly vulnerable to the effects of the US Federal Reserve scaling back its massive monetary stimulus programme. This is in part due to their large current account deficits. We look at how well these countries - which all face elections in 2014 - have prepared and what still needs to be done.

Is £15,000 a year enough for a non-executive director? 

Bank of England non-executive directors are paid £15,000 a year, for working three days a month. Some officials say the high-status position deserves a larger salary. "£15,000 is pitiful," said one. "It suggests people are only turning up for the tea." http://on.ft.com/12O9cZ8

By way of comparison: 
Non-executive directors at big banks can be paid more than £50,000. The chairmen of big banks typically get £750,000 in salary. According to the Office of National Statistics, the median wage in the UK is £26,500. 

What do you think? Should Bank of England non-executives be paid more?

Luxembourg - home to companies like Amazon and Skype -  is willing to share currently confidential information about multinationals' bank accounts as part of efforts to shed it's image as a tax haven. What impact will this have on businesses and consumers? 

Put your questions to our tax correspondent, Vanessa Houlder, who will be online on ft.com today (Tuesday) at 1pm London time, 8am New York time. 

You can post questions on ft.com http://on.ft.com/18dKlyv or leave them below.

The Netherlands has 23,000  "letterbox companies" which list their address in the country to take advantage of the low tax regime, despite having little or no business activities there. The Rolling Stones and U2 also have companies in the same 17th-century Amsterdam canal house, taking advantage of the lack of Dutch withholding taxes on royalties. 

The Dutch authorities are now trying to restrict letterbox companies but face resistance from those who say tax advantages attract potential employers to the country. Does it make sense for the Netherlands to keep its taxes low?

Big companies' ability to exploit cracks in the international tax system has angered an austerity-weary public, and policymakers are drawing up plans to close loopholes. But many countries are still looking to cut tax. Does this make sense? Why do countries compete instead of collaborate on tax? 

Put your questions to our tax correspondent, Vanessa Houlder, who will be online on ft.com tomorrow (Tuesday) at 1pm London time, 8am New York time, to answer your questions about tax avoidance. 

You can post questions on ft.com http://on.ft.com/18dKlyv or leave them below.

Would it make you think twice about flying? http://on.ft.com/17mOzpM

The US admits just 225,000 skilled foreigners a year, less than 0.1 per cent of its workforce. This makes it an outlier among wealthy countries. Read more: http://on.ft.com/16FvQmj

My night at the rodeo with China's elite:
As the sun set over a spectacular ridge line, I hesitated to imagine the reaction of the rodeo's riders and roughnecks had they known they were being cheered on by a group of Chinese communists. Even worse, the cadres were in cahoots with a bunch of soggy European liberals. Colorado is a swing state in the presidential election but I saw few likely Democrats. The rodeo was in what an American friend called "gun country". Mitt Romney won the T-shirt vote hands down. http://on.ft.com/QwcOWi

Social media help stars' earnings run and run: 

Olympic athletes are returning home from the London Games, hoping to extend their peak period for endorsement earnings through their increased popularity on social media. 

Athletes traditionally had a short time frame to capitalise on their performance at the Olympics because they quickly faded from the public eye, according to marketing executives. But social media have allowed athletes to extend relationships with fans by sharing messages, photos and videos. Read our story: http://on.ft.com/SeOKsT

Global shift in US business confounds Washington:

In recent years, Tupperware has seemed to epitomise the American dream. But these days those air-tight boxes come with a twist. Four decades ago, 90 per cent of the company's sales were in the US. Now, however, 90 per cent are outside the US. It is not American consumers who are now driving the group's success, but those in Indonesia or Korea or Germany. Read more in Gillian Tett's column: http://on.ft.com/POTdjX

The FT's Gideon Rachman writes: "Five years ago the Americans were refusing to speak to the Taliban. Now the Taliban are refusing to speak to the Americans. status_message:
In the 50 years since Yuri Gagarin first soared into space, 520 people have taken their own space odysseys.  They have come from 38 countries and, in a special issue, FT Weekend Magazine has interviewed an astronaut from 35 of these countries. 

The project involved 17 writers, 11 languages and a rather flustered mission control - but it resulted in stories as diverse and entertaining as the voyagers themselves.
link_name: FT.com / FT Magazine - Meet the astronauts of Planet Earth

Event Spotlight: Hollywood Gets A Social Makeover, hosted by the Financial Times 
As part of their Social Media Week media partnership, the FT are hosting a panel discussion at The Paley Center for Media in Beverley Hills on Wednesday, September 22 from 8:30-10:30am called "Hollywood Gets A Social Makeover". 
Matthew Garrahan, the FT's Los Angeles Correspondent, will moderate the discussion, which will be streamed live (starting at 9 am PT/5 pm GMT) from socialmediaweek.org and paleycenter.org as well as SMW's UStream channel on http://www.ustream.tv/socialmediaweekglobal.

Are you thinking about studying for a masters degree, but not sure what it entails? Or perhaps you are eager to continue your graduate studies but fear you might be a little rusty? Then take a look at the Financial Times Masters Gym at http://mastersgym.ft.com/

This free, online interactive tool gives you an insight into what it might be like to study for a masters degree in finance, accounting, management or marketing. Each gym takes about 15 minutes to complete. A series of interactive slides will give you an introductory flavour of each subject and when you have completed your workout and perhaps want to learn more there is a list of further reading material.

So go on, flex your brain and get yourself down to the masters gym!

status_message:
UK Only – Launched on the 10th January, the 'Take a Friend for a Fiver' promotion, in association with Harden's restaurant guide, will offer readers the chance to take a friend to a leading restaurant for five pounds.

Run between the 10 January and 13 February, diners will be asked to make a booking quoting 'Lunch with the FT' and to then produce three tokens from the newspaper for each couple dining. The bill for food will be halved and a five pound charge will be added for the second diner.* Over 150 of Britain's finest restaurants are participating including Nahm, Scott's, Umu, Vineyard at Stockcross, Daphne's and the Ivy.

Single tokens will also be available in the FT weekday edition from 12 January until 13 February. Two tokens will appear in each edition of the FT Weekend until 7 February.
link_name: 'Lunch with the FT 2009' | in association with Harden's
